Channel Sounding

2024 02 20

To gain a deep understanding of small-scale indoor wireless channel characteristics and the spatial directionality of MIMO systems, our team conducted a comprehensive experimental study. First, time-varying frequency responses across a 0–400 MHz bandwidth were measured at various positions, revealing pronounced frequency-selective fading in the indoor multipath environment. Comparisons of impulse responses under full-, mid-, and narrow-band conditions showed delay spreads on the order of microseconds, with narrower bandwidths yielding less separation between primary and secondary peaks. Doppler spectrum analysis indicated low target velocities, with Doppler spreads confined to –10 Hz to +25 Hz. Finally, MVDR beamforming on data from an 8×8 MIMO array produced a clear main lobe at 0° and secondary lobes around ±40°, pinpointing the direct path and prominent side-reflection angles. This study provides solid experimental foundations for subsequent MIMO receiver design, beamforming strategies, and system optimization.
